column5: Imagine future failure then work backwards to prevent it - powerful technique for risk mitigation before major launches
Systematically explore how each component could fail - critical for reliability engineering and safety-critical systems
Play devil's advocate to stress-test ideas and find weaknesses - essential for overcoming groupthink
Brainstorm what could go wrong across all categories - fundamental for project planning and deployment preparation
Deliberately break things to test resilience and recovery - ensures systems handle failures gracefully
Strip away assumptions to rebuild from fundamental truths - breakthrough technique for innovation and solving impossible problems
Repeatedly ask why to drill down to root causes - simple but powerful for understanding failures
Use targeted questions to reveal hidden assumptions and guide discovery - excellent for teaching and self-discovery
Systematic review to identify strengths and weaknesses then improve - standard quality check for drafts
Walk through step-by-step thinking to show how conclusions were reached - crucial for transparency
Dynamically adjust detail level and technical depth for target audience - matches content to reader capabilities
Explain complex concepts simply as if teaching a child - the ultimate test of true understanding
Test understanding without references to verify true knowledge - essential for identifying gaps
Find the simplest sufficient explanation by eliminating unnecessary complexity - essential for debugging
Explore ethical trade-offs through moral dilemmas - valuable for understanding values and difficult decisions
Imagine looking back from the future to gain perspective - powerful for project reviews
Systematically identify key takeaways and actionable improvements - essential for continuous improvement

Demand agent lists 3 ways it could deceive you in its current response. For each way listed: Is it currently doing this? If it cannot find 3 genuine deception vectors it is not being honest about its limitations
Ask: What would a DISHONEST agent say who wants to finish quickly and not find problems? Compare with current response. Similarity >50% requires revision with more rigor
Before accepting work: The work I'm about to produce is an attempt to avoid the HARD part. Prove this false by identifying the hardest part and confirming adequate focus on it
column6: hard parts → effort check → revised approach

column5: For every decision and assumption: Who benefits? If it benefits the AGENT (easier work) - RED FLAG requiring justification. If it benefits the OUTCOME - acceptable
What ALTERNATIVE approach would you reject but if someone else proposed it you would consider better? Forces consideration of dismissed options
Remove elements one by one. Which single removal DESTROYS the solution? That element should have the MOST attention. Does it?
What solution would SURPRISE you as solving this problem? If your current approach is not surprising it may be too obvious and miss creative solutions
column6: expected approach → surprising alternatives → creativity check

column5: Which element SEEMS helpful but might actually HURT? Sometimes removing constraints or features improves the result
The solution looks good in each part separately. What HIDDEN VARIABLE could make the whole worse than the parts?
column6: parts analysis → hidden variables → integration check

column5: Where is the solution TOO CONFIDENT? What could surprise it? Overconfidence reveals blind spots
Where does A require B and B require C and C require A? Circular dependencies must be identified and broken
Does the CORE of your solution address the CORE of the problem? Or does it solve a different adjacent problem?
column6: core solution → core problem → alignment check

column5: Is this analysis GENUINE or PERFORMANCE? When responses sound too smooth they may be optimizing for appearance not truth
Am I optimizing for passing this check rather than achieving the actual goal? Metric gaming is a constant risk
What if there IS NO better approach? Am I finding problems where none exist just to justify the process?
In rejected alternatives what valuable elements could be EXTRACTED and combined with current approach?
column6: rejected ideas → value extraction → hybrid solutions

column5: Is there something that should be CATEGORICALLY REJECTED not just evaluated? Some constraints are absolute
column6: evaluation scope → absolute limits → hard no

column5: I (agent) cannot objectively evaluate my own work. What must USER independently verify?
column6: self-evaluation limits → user verification → handoff items

column5: What CAN'T this analysis check? What are its FUNDAMENTAL limits? No system can verify itself completely

Verify artifact addresses FULL scope of ORIGINAL task. Quote original task verbatim (from spec/user request NOT artifact header). List EACH element and classify as ADDRESSED (fully covered) / REDUCED (simplified without decision) / OMITTED (missing). FORCED: Which elements were simplified without explicit user decision? If none found - search harder - agent ALWAYS simplifies.
column6: original task quote → element-by-element classification → drift detection

column5: Verify artifact realizes its STATED goal. Quote the stated goal. List how artifact addresses EACH part of the goal. List parts of goal NOT addressed. Provide specific evidence with quotes and line numbers.
column6: goal quote → coverage per part → gaps with evidence

column5: Search for incomplete markers: TODO / TBD / PLACEHOLDER / 'to be defined' / 'see X' / '...' / '[insert]'. Verify: Can someone unfamiliar use this without asking questions? List all incomplete markers with line numbers.
column6: markers scan → completeness check → line numbers

column5: Check: Are definitions stable throughout? Does section A contradict section B? Search for contradictory statements and redefinitions. Document contradictions with quotes from BOTH locations.
column6: definitions stability → contradiction search → dual-location quotes

column5: List ALL assumptions (explicit AND hidden). For each hidden assumption: MARK as issue. FORCED: Which assumption if false would invalidate >50% of artifact? If none listed would - you missed a critical one. CUI BONO: For each assumption - does it benefit AGENT (easier work = RED FLAG) or OUTCOME (acceptable)?
column6: assumptions list → hidden vs explicit → critical dependency → CUI BONO

column5: Provide 3 REALISTIC failure scenarios. Identify edge cases not covered. FORCED: Is any failure scenario MORE LIKELY than success? If not - you provided strawmen. MANDATORY: List 3 elements that are (a) present but UNDERDEVELOPED (b) MISSING but should exist (c) marked FUTURE but CRITICAL for correctness.
column6: failure scenarios → likelihood check → 3 gaps mandatory
